scenes.label: *start
texts: It took us a while, but we found a place illuminated by moonlight.
It looked like a large shaft made to transport materials, and it seemed to connect to the surface.
There were no ladders or steps though, so it was difficult for us to get out through it.
Still, the moonlight alone was soothing enough. I wanted to sit right down and bask in it for a while.
We'd been walking through dark subway tunnels and maintenance passageways for almost half an hour.
...the moment when we were flung out of Oz's car, I honestly thought we were gonna die.
And we probably would've, if we hadn't landed on a pile of soft stuff. That smooth landing probably saved our lives.
After that, we ran into the crater, thinking our pursuers might still have been after us.
The Shinjuku Crater restoration was centered around where Shinjuku Station used to be.
In other words, the rest of the crater was being ignored for now.
That's why there was nobody else around, making it the perfect place to hide.
Momo was constantly looking behind her, like something was following us. She'd been on the run for a while, so I guess she was exhausted.
We needed a moment to cool off and figure out what we were dealing with.
I see... God, at least text me or something.
I couldn't. I had no reception until literally just now.
And here I was, thinking the army had hauled you off.
C'mon. Have I ever failed ya? Hm?
I told him what happened after we were flung from Oz's car.
Speaking of this Oz guy, he just left a comment on the Nakano Symphonies commissions page a moment ago.
I'd been doxxed already? That Oz guy sure was impressive.
He says he wants us to contact him for an info exchange. Who is he?
Dunno, but save that for later.
First, I gotta get the army off our backs. Momo's not safe here.
Momo let out a sudden yelp right as she sat down on a concrete block.
I'm sorry. It was colder than I thought...
She rubbed her butt as she spoke, trying to warm it.
It was the end of November and we were 20 meters underground. Stood to reason the concrete was cold.
Um, please don't mind me. I'm comfortable in this outfit.
It sure looked warm, but it didn't cover her legs.
I looked around for something I could use.
There was a big drum and a load of packaging styrofoam.
According to the news, the army's retreated.
The best place to shelter Momo would be...
Then we'll head back to Symphony. Help us out, bro.
It didn't look like much, but our Symphony hideout had pretty good security.
I mean, it probably wouldn't hold up against the army, but it was better than being here in a goddamn crater.
Plus, I couldn't think of anywhere else.
I saw a 4chan post saying the cops are gathered at the perimeter of the Shinjuku Crater.
You should wait until they leave.
I took the drum and filled it with styrofoam, plus a bunch of other flammable-looking stuff.
How long do you think they'll be around?
And that'd be when we could make our escape, most likely.
Oh, and can you ask Dub to pick up my graper?
After filling the drum with flammable material, I reached into my pouch and took out my multi-tool pocket knife.
I infiltrated all kinds of places on my Nakano Symphonies jobs, so it made sense to keep it at hand.
It even had a lighter on it. Useful little guy.
The motor's damaged. You sure overdid it, huh?
It wasn't me. Those bastards put bullet holes through the rear wheel.
I set the styrofoam on fire as I spoke to Cross. Black smoke billowed out, but it wasn't all that harmful.
Momo walked up closer and clapped.
...Is your gf some sort of VIP?
Leave the graper to me. You keep your girl safe.

scenes.label: *momo
texts: It's not much, though, and it won't last long.
But it was still better than nothing.
Momo watched the fire with a vacant expression. I could only hope her nerves had settled a little.
You're really good at building a fire.
It's a skill I picked up when Sad Morning struck.
It was the middle of winter... Y'know what that means? Without fire, you die. So I had no choice but to learn how to do it.
Momo's face suddenly turned gloomy as she looked up through the shaft, at the sky.
Countless people fell victim to it...
This your first time in a crater?
They were all exclusion zones, but I'd been to the Daikanyama Crater before on some hacker business.
I hadn't seen one either, until I went to Ochanomizu this morning and saw the crater there.
I was shocked... To think that it left scars so vast and deep, the world over...
With each of them claiming so many lives...
Nobody was ready for it. Nobody saw it coming.
People thought nothing of it, like it was someone else's concern. Me included.
There had been warnings that the <tips,21,Year 2036 Problem> would be way worse than <tips,22,Y2K>.
And because of that, experts all over the world did whatever they could to prevent it. I'd heard about that, even as a child.
Back then, it seemed like most people didn't even know what overflow errors might trigger.
But all the adults assured everyone they were prepared for it.
That was why it was such a shock when something actually happened.
There were six <tips,23,SA4D>s that fired at Tokyo. Their targets were...
They were hit at almost the same time.
Y'know, I could've been dead too.
It turned out, there were other cities that were potential targets.
But one of the satellites that was set to strike—SA4D 0144—happened to stop functioning right before it fired.
It wasn't clear which area would've been hit, but for all we knew, it could've been Nakano, which is where I was.
Tons of people died that day. And even if you survived, you most likely lost a family member or someone close to you.
Did... Did you lose someone too?
Yeah. My dad died in Shinbashi.
Huh? Why? You don't have to be sorry.
I tilted my head. She looked at me, and I saw desperation in her eyes.
Anyways...no one had the power to stop what happened that day.
Not the politicians with all their influence on the world stage...
Not the spiritual leaders with their millions of believers...
Not the experts. Not the engineers...
Not even the hackers with mad skills, praised by others as wizards—
Hackers are wizards. We can make anything happen.
I suddenly remembered the saying my dad always came out with.
My dad was a hacker. He worked officially as an engineer, but he had a side-gig doing jobs as a white hat. Companies paid him to test security.
I got my programming skills from him. He taught me when I was young.
He wasn't too passionate about teaching me though, so my skills were still basically third-rate.
He was a real workaholic too. He cared so much about his work that he had no room in his life for me...or family in general.
That's why my mother got fed up with him and left. I hadn't heard from her at all. I had no idea where she was or what she was doing.
That's how it was growing up. And that's why I grew to hate him, and we pretty much stopped talking.
Each of the SA4D attacks hit at different times, depending on the place.
The Year 2036 Problem led to them malfunctioning at the same time, but the attacks weren't simultaneous.
The first payload target was Europe.
Japan was slightly behind them, but only by a few minutes or so.
Still, I had enough time to find out about the SA4D malfunction in Europe and contact my dad.
Dad! Where are you?! You heard what's happening in Europe right n—
Just those cold words, and then he ended the call.
"Hackers are wizards. We can make anything happen."
My dad... Hackers couldn't do shit.
And it didn't matter whether they were script kiddies or the cream of the crop.
None of them could do anything.
I was a hacker too, but I only did it to make a living... I didn't actually like it.
I wanted to be somebody who helped people in ways hackers couldn't.
Hey, Momo... If you need help, I'm right here. You can count on me.
I didn't care if I was being intrusive or nosy or whatever.
If I couldn't help her, I'd just be the same as those hackers...the same as my dad.
But Momo wasn't exactly overjoyed. She didn't even nod. She just sat there with a troubled look on her face.
